Description: Glass pendant with a suspension loop at the top; originally light green; cast, with mould-seams along each side; shows a full-bodied nude female figure in a squatting masturbating position, identified as Baubo; suspension loop broken; fabric decomposed to golden iridescent appearance.
Curator's comments: Originally registered as 'Small, white glass hermaphrodite figure squatting down'. This figure is usually identified as that of Baubo, a coarse midwife of Greek mythology who had a sanctuary dedicated to her at Priene, and who may be equated with a cult in Egypt. She has a varied iconography which nevertheless invariably emphasises her genitalia. A small number of glass pendants, in deep dark blue, opaque yellow or light greenish fabric, have been excavated or reported from Acre, Delos and Egypt; a single example was excavated as far east as Merv in 1994 (St J. Simpson: ' "Baubo" at Merv', 'Parthica' 6 (2004), pp. 227-33). There are also four examples, two from the Slade collection, in the Department of Greek & Roman Antiquities (1868-5-1,6; 1871-6-16,22; 1976-10-1,9; 1976-10-1,10). These pendants are generally believed to have been made in Phoenicia in the 2nd-1st centuries BC, or late Hellenistic and Early Roman Imperial periods.
Condition: Semi-complete, missing suspension loop at the top; fabric decomposed to golden iridescent appearance.
Acquisition name: Division of Finds: Department of Antiquities of Iraq
